message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The coronary steal phenomenon occurs when there is excessive dilation of microvessels in non-ischemic areas of the myocardium, leading to diversion of blood from ischemic areas and worsening of ischemia. Options A and C are not correct because venodilation and arterial dilation do not directly affect blood flow in the coronary vessels. Option D is not correct because volume loss of fluid in the periphery does not affect blood flow in the coronary vessels either.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The coronary steal phenomenon is caused by microvessel dilation, which diverts blood away from ischemic areas of the myocardium and towards areas that already have sufficient blood flow. Venodilation can cause decreased cardiac output, but it is not directly related to the coronary steal phenomenon. Arterial dilation and volume loss of fluid in the periphery are also not involved in the mechanism of coronary steal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The coronary steal phenomenon occurs when a coronary artery dilation causes blood to be diverted from ischemic areas of the myocardium to nonischemic areas. This is caused by microvessel dilation, which leads to an increase in blood flow to the nonischemic areas and reduces blood flow to the ischemic areas.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. In the coronary steal phenomenon, vessel dilation causes blood to be diverted from ischemic areas of the myocardium to areas with already-normal blood flow, worsening the ischemic areas. This is caused by the dilation of microvessels, not arterials or veins. Volume loss of fluid in the periphery is not related to the coronary steal phenomenon.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The coronary steal phenomenon occurs when a dilating agent such as adenosine, causes selective dilation of the normal vessels rather than stenotic vessels, leading to blood being shunted away from the ischemic areas. This is due to the dilation of the microvessels in normal tissue, which diverts blood away from the areas with stenosis leading to a paradoxical decrease of blood flow in the ischemic area. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) microvessel dilation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The coronary steal phenomenon occurs when there is microvessel dilation due to the administration of vasodilators, which redistributes blood from ischemic areas to non-ischemic areas, causing further ischemia. Venodilation and arterial dilation do not contribute to this mechanism. Volume loss of fluid in the periphery is not related to the coronary steal phenomenon.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The coronary steal phenomenon occurs when there is dilation of normal coronary vessels, causing blood to be diverted away from ischemic areas and exacerbating ischemia. This dilation is typically seen in the smaller microvessels rather than larger arteries or veins. Therefore, option (B) - microvessel dilation - is responsible for the coronary steal phenomenon.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The coronary steal phenomenon refers to the diversion of blood from ischemic areas of the myocardium to nonischemic areas due to dilation of healthy vessels. This dilation can be caused by drugs that selectively dilate small blood vessels, which is why microvessel dilation is the responsible factor for the coronary steal phenomenon.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The coronary steal phenomenon occurs when there is dilation of the microvasculature in non-ischemic areas, which redirects blood flow away from ischemic areas and worsens their condition. Venodilation and arterial dilation are not specifically involved in the coronary steal phenomenon, and volume loss of fluid in the periphery is not a factor in this phenomenon.

We refer to a medical textbook or article for help. The coronary steal phenomenon occurs when there is dilation of healthy microvessels in non-ischemic areas of the myocardium, which diverts blood flow away from ischemic areas and worsens their ischemia. Venodilation or arterial dilation alone do not cause this phenomenon. Volume loss of fluid in the periphery is not related to coronary steal phenomenon.
